narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read, write, and speak Persian. By the end of the semester I was able to have a dialogue with another classmate for five minutes entirely in Persian. I was also able to write 2-3 full pages all in Persian. We also learned about Persian culture having biweekly discussions about Iranian cities, poets, writers, art...
I learned the Persian alphabet and the basics of grammar and vocabulary, as well as beginner skills in speaking and listening. We also had several lessons on Persian history and culture.
I learnt a substantial quantity of Persian vocabulary and grammar as well as a fair amount of cultural trivia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Difficult class considering it was L1
You learn how to read and write very well, especially considering it's a level one class. That said, I think we could've worked more on speaking, more specially informal speaking.

Work was somewhat sporadically assigned without a regular predictable pattern, and for several assignments students never received feedback or a grade. The course could be improved by providing more advance notice of assignments, clearer explanation of expectations, and more regular provision of grades/feedback.

The progression through topics is good, ensuring a gradually growing base of words which are consistently used. The cultural topics are also often very interesting, if not directly relevant to actually learning the language. The main weakness is certainly the arbitrary nature of feedback and grading. I often felt as though I was unsure exactly what was going to come up on the test (and sometimes material tested was beyond what we had been told to study), while feedback on performance was often minimal and unhelpful. When I talked to the Professor about this, I would receive generic "work harder" advice rather than anything more targeted on how I could practically improve my performance.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would! But, they should only take this class if they're genuinely interested in learning Persian. It's not an easy class and does take work.

If you are extraordinarily committed to learning the language, yes. If not, no. This is a course that demands a lot of work and effort and your progress is very limited if you do not spend a substantial amount of your time on the language. I would really not recommend this unless you are intending to major in the subject, or have other classes with a low workload. The time spent is not always because the material is challenging, but rather because of the arbitrary and sometimes scattergun nature of assessment - you always have got to be on your toes.
